message_1: Let X be a set with the discrete topology (every subset of X is an open set). Is X compact? If not, provide a counterexample.
message_2:
X is not necessarily compact in the discrete topology. A space is compact if every open cover has a finite subcover. We can provide a counterexample to show that X is not compact in the discrete topology.

Consider the set X = ℕ (the set of natural numbers). In the discrete topology, every subset of ℕ is an open set. Now, let's create an open cover for ℕ:

C = { {n} | n ∈ ℕ }

C is an open cover of ℕ because it consists of open sets (singletons in the discrete topology) and the union of all sets in C is ℕ. However, there is no finite subcover of C that covers ℕ, because ℕ is infinite. If we remove any set from C, the corresponding natural number will not be covered.

Since we found an open cover without a finite subcover, ℕ with the discrete topology is not compact. This serves as a counterexample to show that a set with the discrete topology is not necessarily compact.
